Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Story:
I sat in the break room at the ambulance station, my phone buzzing quietly in my pocket. It was Sunday afternoon, and I knew my parents expected a message from me—just a simple text to let them know I was okay. I could almost hear my mom’s voice in my head, gentle but persistent: “Don’t forget to check in, even if you’re busy.” I pulled out my phone, thumb hovering over the screen, trying to think of something reassuring to say. 

Just then, the radio crackled to life. “Unit 3, possible cardiac arrest, respond immediately.” My heart jumped. I was trained to drop everything and move, to be the first line of help for someone in crisis. But my parents’ last message blinked on the screen, unread. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my duty to my family, who worried in silence, and my duty to strangers who needed me now. My fingers trembled as I stared at the phone, torn between sending a quick message and racing to the ambulance bay, knowing that every second mattered in both roles.
